_desc.NAICS_DESCRIPTION: Cutting Tool and Machine Tool Accessory Manufacturing

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
f a facility is no longer subject to the regulation, the owner or operator shall re-submit a revised registration to EPA within six months indicating that the facility is no longer covered.
Based on our review of available information during our January 28, 2003 audit, there was a program level change since February 2000 that required re-submittal of the electronic RMP.  More specifically, the facility uses propane for heating and for hardening (heat treating) metals.  Since the facility uses propane as a source of carbon in their hardening process, the original RMP was developed to comply with the requirements of the OSHA PSM.  The EPA RMP regulation requires that facilities subject to OSHA PSM regulations be categorized as Program 3 facilities.
We inadvertently categorized Starrett's as a Program 2 facility in the initial February 2000 RMP submittal.  We updated and resubmitted the RMP information on May 9, 2003 to indicate that Starrett's is a Program 3 facility.  We also updated administrative changes in the RMP submittal form (e.g. contact names).
Based on our review of available information since 2003, there were minor changes that would require re-submittal of the electronic RMP. These changes include more accurate latitude and longitude coordination for the tank (i.e. actual location of tank vs. address of facility) and updated population counts for the hazard assessment.
The photographs found in the executive summary of the RMP represent conditions at the time of the initial RMP development.  The facility photo-documents changes made at the facility as a result of the PHA recommendations. The photos typically include a written description of the specific PHA corrective action.  
2.0    MANAGEMENT SYSTEM 
The site specific RMPC has been identified as Joe Sumner.  Please note that the RMPC is a collective term that refers to the overall RMP program managers as well as anyone these individuals may designate to assist them with the implementation of this program.

not included in this executive summary.
The initial information was provided to the general public including the Local/State Emergency Planning Commission (LEPC) and the local fire department/HAZMAT response team through correspondence dated June 14, 2000 and the public meeting held on June 27, 2000.  The local agencies also receive a copy of the emergency response plan (periodically upon updating) and Tier II forms (annually).  Emergency personnel also tour the facility on periodic basis to familiarize themselves with chemical hazards at the Starretts.
Based on our review of available information, the affected population numbers increased since 2000 because of 1) more conservative population density measurements used in models, 2) new census data, and 3) updated latitude and longitude references. This updated information is incorporated into the 2008 EPA re-submittal.
4.0 PROCESS SAFETY INFORMATION 
Important health and safety information must be readily available for the chemical and processes for a variety of reasons (e.g., emergencies, equipment maintenance, etc.).  A listing of the information is included in Section 4.4 of the RMP.

A significant amount of this information can be found primarily throughout the RMP document.  However, the facility periodically reviews the list found in Section 4.4 of the RMP, as well as the written compliance programs, and provides additional information when necessary (e.g., equipment manuals, inspection records, etc.).  A separate process safety file is maintained for RMP documentation at the facility, which includes equipment such as ovens, heaters, etc.

5.0 PROCESS HAZARD ANALYSIS 
A Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) was performed at the facility and is included in Section 5.5 of the RMP. In addition, Paul Johnson Engineering Company performed a Fire and Safety Analysis of the propane system on May 6, 1986, which was included in the original RMP.  This was the approximate time of the 1987 propane tank installation.
PHAs have b

een completed for the process on May 13, 1999, October 20, 2004, and May 13, 2008. Appropriate personnel from Tighe & Bond, Starretts, or contractors participated in these PHAs.  The PHA identified a number of action items along with priority codes.  Upon completion of these activities, the corrective actions are documented and the information is filed with the process safety information.  As previously discussed, photo-documentation of corrective actions (when applicable) are included in the Executive Summary of the RMP. 
A number of PHA items have been completed since the original PHA.  These are designated as "Action Complete" or "AC".  A number of items require "No Further Action" or "NFA" after facility review.  Several other items t are being addressed in accordance with recommended time frames.
6.0 OPERATING INSTRUCTIONS 
Standard Operating procedures either existed or were developed for the facility.  These include programs such as lockout/tagout, confined space, hot work permit, chemical procedures, etc.  A number of these programs have standard operating procedures and checklist which are requisite for documenting regulatory compliance, particularly for the regulated processes.  The instructions for completion of the forms are included in the RMP document.  Starretts completes these forms and maintains documentation in the facility files.  
Operating procedures in this document were developed by Tighe & Bond in association with information provided by the facility's operators.  The operating procedures were reviewed by the RMPC prior to implementation and are reviewed annually thereafter.  The revisions are incorporated into this document.  The header and the cover page of the RMP document are updated to show the last revision date.
7.0 TRAINING
Individuals who work on the process at the facility have been provided specific training on the hazards of the process as well as the safe and proper operating procedures.  Individuals who have been certified in th

e process are included in the training certification documentation.  Any new employees who are expected to operate or work on this process are provided specific operational training and included in the training certification list.
Initial regulatory training was provided on February 25, 1999.  Additional propane hazard and emergency response training was performed on May 6, 1999.  The training outlines and evaluation quizzes can be found in the facility's Process Safety file.
The facility has a regular training schedule that is shown in Section 7.0 of the RMP.  The operators were provided their three-year refresher training on regulated chemical operations on February 28, 2003, January 24, 2006, and July 8, 2008.
New employees or contractors receive appropriate training in accordance with Section 7.5 of the RMP (e.g. emergency procedures, hazard communications, etc.).
8.0 MECHANICAL INTEGRITY
The facility ensures the integrity of process equipment by determining that the equipment is maintained, designed, installed and operating properly.  The primary emphasis behind mechanical integrity is preventative maintenance.  The majority of process equipment has standard operating manuals and maintenance procedures that are kept in the office file.
The facility ensures that recommended maintenance is performed on process equipment in accordance with manufacturer's recommendations.  In addition, modifications to existing systems are performed in accordance with manufacturer's recommendations.  
Starretts certifies that the regulated process systems were designed in accordance with recognized engineering standards at the time of original construction and during subsequent renovations or modifications.  These systems were also inspected during the Process Hazard Analysis. Starretts follows the manufacturer's recommendations for maintenance and inspection.
In certain instances, contractors are used to provide regular maintenance inspections of equipment. Work orders for the ann

ual work are maintained as documentation of propane system maintenance.  The forms found in Section 8.0 of the RMP are also used to periodically (e.g. annually) document maintenance activities.  A safe work permit is also completed during these maintenance activities. 
9.0    MANAGEMENT OF CHANGE 
The facility establishes and implements written procedures to manage any change to the facility or to the process chemicals (e.g., introduction of new chemicals).  This procedure is implemented by using the Management of Change forms (MOC) found in Section 9.5 of the RMP.  
These forms provide a system that evaluates potential changes to the system and potential effects on the process safety operation.  The forms are completed any time there is a change to the process that could affect the overall safety of the chemical system.  All RMPC designees are familiar with this process.
There have been minor changes to the system since the implementation of the RMP and PSM (e.g. replacement of relief valves).  This work on the system is considered "replacement in kind", which means identical replacement parts were used.
10.0    PRE-START SAFETY REVIEW 
The facility performs pre-startup safety reviews for new or modified facilities.  The checklist found in Section 5 (PHA) of the RMP provides the necessary information to review and evaluate potential modifications to the existing process.  This process is started as soon as possible in the conceptual design of the project.
If there are any renovations or facility changes that would impact the process systems, the forms found in Section 10.4 (Action Item Documentation) of the RMP are completed and action items are incorporated into the project.  Appropriate changes are also incorporated into standard operating procedures (e.g. lockout/tagout, emergency plan, operating procedures, etc.).  These are made through Section 9 (Management of Change Procedure) of the RMP. There have been no significant changes which would require Pre-Start-Up Safe

ty Reviews.
11.0    COMPLIANCE AUDITS 
Comprehensive compliance audits are performed at least every three years, while some specific programs (e.g., operating procedures, lockout/tagout, etc.) are reviewed annually by the RMPC or his designees.  The facility also reviews these latter programs during training. Comprehensive audits of the regulated processes at the facility have been performed on January 28, 2003 and January 13, 2006 that identified a number of requirements Starretts must follow. Starretts documents compliance in writing with these audit findings upon completion of each task.
12.0    INCIDENT INVESTIGATION
The facility investigates every incident that results in, or could have reasonably resulted in, a catastrophic release of highly hazardous chemicals within 48 hours of the incident. The standard investigation system for evaluating these types of accidents is included in Section 12.4 of the RMP.  This includes an investigation form that must be completed at the time of the accident.
Upon completion of this activity, a group of individuals investigates and determines why the accident took place.  Recommendations for corrective actions are provided, implemented, and documented.  This minimizes the potential for reoccurrence of future similar accidents.
On February 23, 1997, Starrett had a vaporizer fire in their propane system.  Because the exact quantity of release was unknown, an estimation was incorporated into the RMP Submittal.  Based on the vaporizer operation, five pounds of propane was estimated to be released to the atmosphere.  The emergency shut-off valves were closed by the Athol Fire Department to extinguish the flames.  Both vaporizers were replaced after this accident.
Another minor incident occurred on July 26, 1999 while the propane tank was being drained for repairs.  An estimated quantity of nine pounds was released from the system.  The incident was investigated and the reports are shown in Section 12.0 (Incident Investigation) of the RMP

.  The contractor (Eastern Propane) did not follow the flaring procedure for emptying the tank as described in Section 6.9 (Tank Purge and Flare Procedure).  Contractors will follow Tank Purge and Flare Procedures as required in the Safe Work Permit Section 6.19 for all future work.
Ice damming of the river in the winter of 2004/2005 caused high waters near the propane tank.  The water did not affect the tank or piping and did not cause any releases of propane.  The tank was shut down as a safety measure at the discretion of the propane supplier.  The tank is secured to the saddles to minimize the potential of the tank becoming buoyant during a flood.  Starretts currently has a procedure in the RMP for addressing RMP propane components after flooding.
13.0    EMPLOYEE PARTICIPATION
Employees are one of the key components in safety management systems.  The facility involves employees for the implementation of this plan as follows:
* Employees are involved in safety procedure development and the PHA
* Employees are provided periodic training at regular safety meetings
* Safety meetings empower employees to recommend and implement corrective actions
* A process has been implemented to consider employee recommendations
Employee recommendations are incorporated into H&S procedures, where applicable.  Safety committee activities continue to be documented to ensure employee participation.
14.0    HOT WORK PERMITS 
This system provides a process whereby each heat producing work activity is evaluated and controlled to prevent fires.  Efforts are made to ensure that the entire facility completes hot work permits if the activity is outside a dedicated fire protected areas (e.g. shop).  This minimizes the potential for catastrophic fires that could affect the regulated process.  The instruction and permits are found in Section 14.0 of the RMP.  The hot work permits are on file for work performed in the facility.
15.0    CONTRACTORS
The facility informs contract employers of the potentia

l hazards of the process and ensures that they are trained to awareness level only. Before working in and around hazardous processes, these contractors are provided the facility's safety requirements and notification forms found in Section 15.0 of the RMP and complete a safe work permit. Safe Work Permits are also completed during regulated system servicing.
Contractor evaluation forms are sent to affected contractors.  Completed evaluation forms can be found at the end of Section 15.0 of the RMP.

16.0 EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM  
Section 16.0 of the RMP establishes a plan that deals with emergency situations at the facility to include the handling of small chemical releases.  A standard emergency evacuation plan is also available for the facility.  It should be noted that specific emergency measures can also be found in the operating procedures for regulated processes in Section 6.0 of the RMP.
This information has been provided to the general public (e.g. Local/State Emergency Planning Commission (LEPC) and the local fire department/HAZMAT response team) through correspondence dated June 14, 2000 and the public meeting held on June 27, 2000.  The local agencies also receive a copy of the emergency response plan (periodically upon updating) and Tier II forms (annually).  Emergency personnel also tour the facility on a periodic basis to familiarize themselves with chemical hazards at Starretts.
Starretts Emergency Response program for the facility has been coordinated with Mr. James Wright, who is Chairman of the Local Emergency Planning Commission (LEPC) and Chief of the Athol Fire Department.  Tighe & Bond met with the LEPC on May 21, 1999 to overview the Starrett RMP.
17.0 TRADE SECRETS 
The RMP provides for protection of trade secrets incidental to the process.  The facility currently has no trade secrets that have been disclosed and, therefore, does not require compliance with this particular area of the standard.
